head.title: Journal of a Passage in a Canoe from Pais Plat in Lake Superior to Portage de l'Isle in River Ouinipique, 1784. - Page #10

body.p: << First Page | < Previous Page | Page #10 of 32 | Next Page > | Last Page >>

td.p: Umfreville, Edward. Journal of a Passage in a Canoe from Pais Plat in Lake Superior to Portage de l'Isle in River Ouinipique, 1784. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0030

div.p: June 28 Monday. The last night we were oblig'd to keep 2 men continually up to Guard our Things, the Villian being always ready to break ye Canoe. This morning I consulted with Mr St Germaine on our Situation, being entirely without a Guide & no prospect of procuring one. I must confess I never was more uneasy, well knowing it is impossible to make our Journey, while this fellow is in our Co[.] One of the Indians here has offer'd to conduct us to a place call'd Tête de Bête Puante, which is in our road, but this man has 8 Persons in family, & we must maintain them, or be retarded on the Journey while he goes a hunting, consequently our Provisions will be in no condition to continue the Journey farther, & farther he does not know the way – & even when we are there, the obtaining a Guide to Port de l'Isle is very precarious – reflecting on these matters, we resolv'd to return to the other end of Port. de Petit jour & there wait the return of the French People, fish not being in Sufft plenty where we are to save the corn. But thank God, our gloomy apprehensions were in a great measure obliterated in the afternoon by the arrival of a Canoe, with a Frenchman & Indn in it. The former is call'd Constant, & is a Guide in the service of Monsr Cotè, 60 packs has been made this winter in his Quarter, but 4 of their men have been Eat by the Savages tho' extremity of hunger. Constant says a Canadian is near hand, who is not at present engag'd to any one, is well acquainted with the Road, & not at pres he thinks will be willing to engage with us. This is a prize not to be lost, & that we may see him as soon as possible, mean to send after him to-morrow. This man says we may reach Lac Rouge in 15 days from hence, but adds the Insd the Inds on the road are not very friendly. Made Roy a present for aiding St Germe[.]

29 Tuesday. Mr St Germaine set off this morning, with the man that arrived yesterday, in quest of the man we are in hopes to engage. I staid with the men to guard our Things. They return'd in the Evening. He is nam'd Pierre Bonneau. [H]e knows the way as far as Sturgeon lake, wch he says is above half the way, & the greatest part of the Portages over. To-morw he means to give us his determination.

30 Wednesday. This day & last night proved remarkable Tempestuous. We made our agreemt with Bonneau to guide us to Sturgeon lake, & farther he is not content to go; we wish'd much to engage him to winter but found it impossible. The Goods he is to receive for his Trouble is specified in his Agreemt of wch he has a Copy. What other things he may occasionally receive, I shall notice, & God willing leave this place To-morrow early. This the 12th day since we left the last Port. the other side of lac Nippigon, & this is absolutely not 2 days paddling. Lat. by 2 Alts 50°02'. One Canoe of Nippigon Inds & 2 Canoes in the Service of Mr Coté came to us to day.
July 1st Thursday. Made ye Indians a prest of Tobacco Powder & Shot & departed[.]

in lavender , modifications made by the assumed author(s).
